Dear James Risinger:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code COF Rule 400.10157 Health services; policies and procedures
Title & (1) A facility shall establish and follow written health service
Section policies and procedures that address all of the following:
Description (a) Routine and emergency medical and dental care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
1

Allegation Youth was denied a doctor visit for stomach pain and was given
medicine instead. Youth was provided depression medication
against parental wishes.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 8/21/24.
Complainant reported Youth A has been having trouble sleeping,
eating, and his stomach has been bothering since being at the
facility. Complainant reported his face is sunken in and it looks like
he has lost weight. Complainant reported Youth A was begging to
go to the hospital for his stomach pain but was provided
medication instead.
Complainant reported Nurse called her and apologized for not
contacting her prior to giving Youth A anxiety medication.
Complainant reported Nurse told her Youth A had already had 7
doses, but Complainant told Nurse not to give him anymore until
she could investigate the medication and decide. Complainant
reported Nurse stopped the medication and informed her Youth A
could also refuse the medication at any time in the future.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 8/22/24.
Youth A reported a week ago, he was having stomach pain and
threw up, but his stomach kept hurting. Youth A reported he was
crying and complaining in his room. Youth A reported multiple staff
(couldn’t remember who) came to check on him and asked him
what he needed. Youth A reported he told them he needed to go
to the hospital, but all the staff did was encourage him to eat.
Youth A reported he tried to eat 3 different times, but his body
wouldn’t let him. Youth A reported he was left in his room the rest
of the day with no relief. Youth A reported the following day he
saw Nurse, and he was prescribed a medication to help with
stomach acid. Youth A reported after 2-3 days, he stopped taking
it because he didn’t feel it was helping. Youth A reported his
stomach pain lessened while taking the medication, but it was still
on and off a bit. Youth A reported the stomach pain had been
happening on and off since before he was placed at the facility.
He stated he had gone to a doctor one time to address it, but he
couldn’t remember what the doctor said about it, what he did for
him, or how long the pain had been happening.
Youth A reported he was seen by Nurse on another occasion, and
he was prescribed an anti-depressant for anxiety. Youth A
reported he had never been on the medication before. Youth A
reported he thought his mom approved the medication but found
out later she didn’t. Youth A reported he stopped taking the
medication about 2 days ago because he said it wasn’t helping
2

anything. Youth A reported Nurse told him it would take 2 weeks
to take effect, but he didn’t want to wait that long for it to work, so
he stopped taking it.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
8/22/24. Supervisor reported on or about 8/16/24, Youth A had
written a letter to his girlfriend stating he was going to try to break
out of the facility. Later that same day, Youth A began complaining
about having stomach pains. Supervisor reported Youth A had
only been at the facility for 5-6 days and had only been eating
small bites of food each day. Supervisor reported Youth A said he
was starving himself because he would rather die than be at the
facility. Supervisor reported when Youth A was complaining about
stomach pains, he was screaming at her and demanding to go to
the hospital. Supervisor reported she asked him about his
symptoms, whether he had thrown up, what kind of pain it was,
etc. but he wouldn’t provide any information. Supervisor informed
Youth A she couldn’t consult with medical professionals if he
wouldn’t provide more information, but he still refused. Supervisor
asked if he was nauseous, spoke to him about the possibility of
anxiety, but he still didn’t provide any information. Supervisor
reported she wasn’t willing to send him straight to the emergency
room without further information or consultation with medical
professionals because of Youth A’s plan to break out of the
facility, which was disclosed earlier in the day. Supervisor reported
despite the lack of information, she contacted the on-call medical
doctor, who encouraged her to provide Youth A with a “sick tray”
(Gatorade, popsicle, chicken noodle soup and crackers) since he
hadn’t been eating much. Supervisor provided Youth A with the
“sick tray”, and she told him he needed to eat all of it per the
doctor’s recommendation. Youth A chose to only eat the popsicle,
and continued to complain about his stomach; however, Youth A
fell asleep shortly after. Supervisor reported since Youth A fell
asleep and was content, they didn’t do anything else medically
that night.
Nurse was interviewed face to face at the facility on 8/22/24.
Nurse reported Youth A filled out a slip on 8/16/24 stating he was
having stomach pain and vomiting. Nurse reported she met with
Youth A and consulted with Doctor via text. Doctor said Youth A
could have one Tums once per day for three days, and prescribed
Omeprezole/Prilosec for acid reflux. Nurse reported the
prescription was filled on 8/19/24, so Youth A continued with one
Tums once daily (8/16/24, 8/17/24 and 8/18/24) until the
prescription was filled.
3

Nurse reported on the same slip from 8/16/24 regarding stomach
pain, Youth A made a request for “Buspar”, which is short for
“Buspirone”, which is an anti-anxiety medication. Nurse reported
in speaking with Youth A, he stated he had previously taken the
medication prior to being at the facility. When Nurse met with
Youth A, she believed some of his stomach pain was a result of
anxiety because he had been very tearful and expressed a lot of
concerns about being away from his girlfriend and family. Nurse
consulted with Doctor and Doctor ordered a prescription for
Buspirone (10 mg. twice per day), which was filled the same day.
Nurse reported Youth A took the medication from 8/16/24-8/18/24,
refused his dose in the morning of 8/19/24, but took his dose in
the evening of 8/19/24. Nurse reported he has not taken the
medication since 8/20/24 because Youth A’s mother requested
Youth A stop the medication since it was provided without her
knowledge or approval. Nurse reported she called Youth A’s
mother on 8/20/24 to apologize to her and his mother was very
angry. Nurse talked to Youth A’s mother twice that day to sort
everything out, and his mother ended the conversation by stating
she didn’t know if she wanted Youth A to continue the medication
and would call back later to provide her decision. Nurse admitted
responsibility for not calling Youth A’s mother for approval prior to
starting the psychotropic medication, and admitted it was her
error.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Monroe County Youth Center Medical request dated
8/16/24 for Youth A states “stomach pain/vomiting and
Buspar request”.
• Youth A’s medication log notes Youth A took an Antacid
once daily from 8/16/24-8/18/24. It notes Youth A began
taking Omeprazole/Prilosec once daily from 8/19/24-
8/22/24. It also notes Youth A took Buspirone starting the
evening of 8/16/24 through the evening of 8/18/24, refused
his dose in the morning on 8/19/24, took his dose in the
evening of 8/19/24, and took both of his doses on 8/20/24.
It notes Youth A has not taken Buspirone since 8/20/24.
• Youth A’s prescriptions were viewed and match what is
documented on the medication log as well as the
prescription dates Nurse reported.
• Consent for Treatment with Psychotropic Medications form
for Youth A dated 8/14/24 states Youth A wasn’t on any
medications upon intake.
4

• Receiving/Storing/Releasing Medication policy and
Dispensing Medications policy do not outline the process
required for parental consent for beginning psychotropic
medications.
• Email from Chief Administrator (CA) dated 8/27/24 states
the process for obtaining parental consent prior to
psychotropic medications doesn’t appear to be outlined in
any policies. CA noted the practice is leaving a voicemail
for a parent is not sufficient, and a conversation over the
phone with a parent is required to provide verbal consent.
• Juvie Specific Documentation form states verbal parental
consent is needed for any type of psychotropic medication
change or start. CA noted this form was provided to Nurse
on 6/24/24 via email for training purposes.
• Medical progress note dated 8/20/24 at 14:30 authored by
Nurse describes the contact Nurse made with Youth A’s
mother after she learned Youth A’s mother was upset about
not providing consent for the psychotropic medication to
begin. Nurse admitted to Youth A’s mother she
inadvertently omitted calling her prior to starting the
medication.
• Medical progress note dated 8/20/24 at 15:10 authored by
Nurse describes the follow-up contact Nurse had with
Youth A’s mother after retrieving Youth A’s medication log.
Nurse also described the side effects, dosage, pros and
cons about the medication.
• Nurse does not have any disciplinary records in her
employee file. Nurse was trained on procedures related to
medication consent on 6/24/24.
Analysis The agency is found in violation as per interviews conducted and
documentation reviewed, Nurse failed to follow the facility’s
procedure regarding obtaining parental consent prior to starting
Youth A on a psychotropic medication.
There were no findings regarding the facility’s response to Youth
A having a stomachache. They asked questions, contacted a
medical professional, and followed the medical advice.
5

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It is recommended the facility update their medication policies to
include the process for obtaining parental consent for medications
and specify which types of medications need consent prior to use.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10169 Discipline
Section (1) A facility shall have and follow written policy and procedure
Description which stipulates that residents shall not be subjected to any of the
following: (a) Corporal or cruel punishment.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A has been slapped by two staff.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 8/21/24.
Complainant reported she spoke with Youth A on the phone within
the last week and their conversation was being monitored by the
facility. Complainant reported Youth A wouldn’t talk a lot, so she
asked him a lot of questions. Complainant reported it wasn’t clear,
but she believed Youth A stated 5-6 days prior to their
conversation, Youth A was slapped by two staff. Complainant
reported she did not get any other details and was unaware of the
staff’s names.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 8/22/24.
Youth A reported he was never slapped or hit by any staff at the
facility. Youth A reported Complainant was mistaken, and he isn’t
sure why she said it.
Analysis The agency is not found in violation as per the interview
conducted with Youth A, he reported he has not been slapped or
hit by any staff at the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
